entries.text: Yanick reminds us that the end is nigh. In this case, the end of Twitter's support of version 1 of their REST API (which is due for June 11th). Is your code, and the plugins of your web framework updated and ready to weather the storm?
entries.title: Are You Ready For the Atwitterpocalypse?

entries.text: It was Brent Laabs's first YAPC. He liked it.
entries.title: Thanking the Perl Community for an Awesome YAPC

entries.text: Did you know that, up to perl v5.18, the vertical tab wasn't part of the \s character class. Or, let's be honest: did you even remember that there is such a thing as a vertical tab? brian d foy reviews for us how the space classes changed between perl v5.10 and v5.18.
entries.title: The vertical tab is part of \s in Perl 5.18

entries.text: Want to know, bullet-point-style, what's new in perl v5.18. brian d foy gives it to you, unadorned.
entries.title: Perl 5.18 new features

entries.text: Perl v5.18 has this new experimental feature that warns if your code use things that are not totally set in stone yet. brian d foy goes over the features that trigger experimental warnings and, just as important, shows us how to hush those  warnings.
entries.title: Experimental features now warn (reaching back to v5.10)

entries.text: You have test fixtures that you need to run in a certain order.  So you name them 'aaa_first()', 'bbb_second()', right? Wrong! That's a classic anti-pattern, and Ovid shows us how to deal with ordering fictures in a much more elegant way.
entries.title: A Test::Class Anti-Pattern

entries.text: When writing slidedecks, you want the presentation software to be as inobstrusive as possible. In fact, you probably want writing slides to be as easy as jolting notes on your favorite editor. That's pretty much what Buddy Burden thought, too. Hence, meet Vroom, a vi-based slideshow.
entries.title: Slideshows in Vroom: So Noted

entries.text: Every hacker, sooner or later, will come up with their own template system or blog engine. In this instance, Yanick comes up with the second generation of his blog engine. And his own templating system. And a few other things.
entries.title: Galuga Reborn!

entries.text: You missed YAPC::NA? Well, you're in luck: Brian Wisti has compiled as much of the links to the videos and slides of the talks as it is humanly possible in this blog entry.
entries.title: YAPC::NA 2013 Links From a Non-Attendee

entries.text: David Wheeler was in Ottawa a few weeks ago, and gave a talk entitled "Agile Database Development with Git, Sqitch, and pgTAP". Here are the slidedeck'ed evidences.
entries.title: Agile Database Development Tutorial

entries.text: Just in case the YAPC::NA videos aren't enough for your visual appetite.
entries.title: Videos from the Polish Perl Workshop

entries.text: It began with a Catalyst talk. They wanted more. So Laufeyjarson now talks about DBIx::Class.
entries.title: DBIx::Class Talk at SVPerl

header: YAPC::NA came and went and, by all accounts seen so far, was a smashing success. For those not fortunate enough to have been present, a plethora of videos and slidedecks are now flooding YouTube and the various blogs -- hunt these down in the 'Slides and Videos' section.  Beside those talk links, this week has been fairly quiet, a side-effect of having a huge portion of the Perl community being busy having a jolly good time. However, fear not: we can safely expect blogging volumes to return to normal next week, as hackers slowly trickle back to their keyboards. ~Yanick
subject: YAPC is Over, Reruns Season on YouTube Just Begins
